thread.title: Governor of Russia's Kemerovo region resigns after deadly shopping mall fire

title: Governor of Russia's Kemerovo region resigns after deadly shopping mall fire
text:
April 1, 2018 / 5:38 AM / Updated 36 minutes ago Governor of Russia's Kemerovo resigns over deadly mall fire Reuters Staff 2 Min Read 
MOSCOW (Reuters) - The governor of Russia’s Kemerovo region resigned on Sunday over a mall fire that killed more than 60 after a litany of violations in safety procedures left shoppers and children trapped inside the building. Governor of the Kemerovo Region Aman Tuleyev speaks during a meeting in Kemerovo, Russia March 7, 2018. Picture taken March 7, 2018. REUTERS/Maxim Lisov 
Aman Tuleyev, 73, said in a video posted on the regional administration’s website that stepping down was the only course of action possible. President Vladimir Putin accepted his resignation, the Kremlin said. 
“With such a heavy burden, it’s impossible to work as the governor,” Tuleyev said. “It’s morally impossible.” 
Last Sunday’s fire, one of the deadliest in Russia since the break-up of the Soviet Union, swept through a cinema complex and children’s play area on the upper floors of the Winter Cherry shopping centre in the regional capital. 
Investigators said last week that fire exits had been illegally blocked, the public address system was not switched on, the alarm system was broken, and children had been locked inside cinemas. 
Putin said the incident had been caused by criminal negligence and that those responsible would be punished. 
On Sunday he appointed Sergei Tsivilyov, one of the region’s deputy governors, to replace Tuleyev as acting governor. 
On Friday, police arrested an executive with the firm that owns the shopping mall. 
The calamitous way the emergency was handled stirred public anger in Kemerovo and focused attention on corruption and lax fire safety standards. Rallies commemorating the victims were held across the country, including in Moscow and St Petersburg. Reporting by Gabrielle Tétrault-Farber; editing by John Stonestreet
